headline: Nixon, With Wife, to Visit 3 Chinese Cities in 7 Days
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 — The White House announced today that President Nixon's journey to China in February would take him to three cities in seven days for “free‐wheel ing” discussions with Premier Chou En‐lai and Chairman Mao Tse‐tung. He will be accom panied by Mrs. Nixon.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

author: By Douglas Robinson;Special to The New York Times

headline: RULES ON WAR NEWS TIGHTENED BY SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov'30 (UPI)——South Vietnam insti tuted new ground rules for news coverage of military oper ations today and threatened to expell correspondents for viola tions.

headline: How Many Secrecies?
lead_paragraph: LIVERMORE, Calif.—Here are three examples: the secrecy of the Kremlin, the secrecy of Washington, and the secrecy of The New York Times.
author: By Edward Teller

headline: New Drive Reported Opened in Central Highlands
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 1—About 15, 000 Government troops have reportedly begun a thrust against enemy forces in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam near the Cambodian border.
author: By Iver Peterson;Special to The New York Times

headline: Wild Blue Yonder Revisited
lead_paragraph: The United States Air Force Academy glistens metallically at the foot of an endless range of lovely mountains near Colorado Springs. The chapel building catches your eyes first as you approach it across the valley. Constructed of steel and aluminum, it tapers from a broad base to a series of points thrusting assertively upward toward the wild blue yonder. It was on the steps of this chapel that I, along with several other people, was apprehended by Air Force Security Police last month for distributing a prayer of St. Francis of Assisi and four quotations from the Bible. The prayer is the familiar one that starts out, “Lord, make me en instrument of Thy peace. Where there is hatred, let me sow love,” etc. The Bible verses had to do with beating swords into plowshares and not studying war anymore.
author: By Harvey Cox

headline: Foe in Cambodia Renews Heavy Attacks
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Dec. 1 (AP)—North Vietnamese forces renewed heavy attacks along Cambodia's northeastern front today and Cambodian troops were reported retreating from two key towns.

headline: Henderson Jury Awaits Three New Witnesses
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 1—The military jury at the courtmartial of Col. Oran K. Henderson marked time today while awaiting the arrival of three, witnesses who it expects will shed more light on whether there was a coverup of they Mylai 4 slayings.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. PRESSES ISSUE OF PRISONER MAIL
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 2—William J. Porter, the American delegate to the Vietnam peace talks, pressed North Vietnam again today to permit “a normal flow of mail” from American prisoners held there.

headline: Heavy Casualties Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 3 (AP)—A 120‐man company of South Vietnamese militiamen suffered heavy casualties yesterday in a clash with North Vietnamese troops 48 miles northwest of Saigon, the South Vietnamese command reported today. It said that 24 troops had been killed and 15 had been wounded in the action near the headquarters for current South Vietnamese operations in eastern Cambodia. The command said the militia force killed 32 enemy soldiers.

headline: CAMBODIA'S DRIVE COLLAPSES IN FACE OF ENEMY ATTACK
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 2 — Thousands of Cambodian Government troops were reported in disorderly retreat today as a major military campaign north of the capital collapsed in the face of heavy North Vietnamese attacks.

headline: 2 PARTY OFFICIALS DIFFER ON ISSUES
lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee said yesterday: that the economy would be the major issue of the Democratic party in the 1972 election.
author: By Alfonso A. Narvaez

headline: U.S. Combat Toll for Week Put at 9 Killed, 78 Wounded
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 2 (UPI) — The United States command reported today that nine Americans were, killed and 78 wounded in combat in Indochina last week.

headline: Vietcong Announces Truces for 3 Holidays
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 3 (AP)—The Vietcong's Liberation Radio announced today that Viet‐, cong troops in South Vietnam would observe ceasefires for the Christmas and New Year's holidays and also for the Tet lunar new year in February.

headline: Skirmishes in East Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 2 (PI) — Only minor skirmishes were reported today in the 11‐day‐old South Vietnamese sweep through the rubber plantation country of Eastern Cambodia.

headline: U. S. Pilots Report First Attack by North Vietnamese MIG on a B‐52
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 2—American pilots here said today that a North Vietnamese MIG fighter fired airto‐air missiles at an American Air Force B‐52 bomber over the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos about 10 days ago, but missed and was chased back into North Vietnam.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Victim of Russian Roulette
lead_paragraph: HARTSHORNE, Okla., Dec. 3 (AP) — While four companions shouted for him to put a pistol down, a young man killed himself today in a demonstration of Russian roulette. The police said that Stephen Carl Gaylor, 21 years old, put a cartridge in the pistol, spun the chamber and fired it, then repeating this twice, despite pleas to stop, before killing himself on the third try. Mr. Gaylor was a Vietnam war veteran.

headline: Podell Tells of His ‘Qualification’—Money
author: By Richard L. Madden; Special to The New York Times

headline: CONFEREES FAIL AGAIN ON AID BILL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — A compromise foreign‐aid bill that would authorize $2.75‐billion in economic and military assistance remained blocked today in a House and Senate conference committee by disagreement over an amendment calling for withdrawal of all United States troops from. Indochina within a specified time.

headline: A Former Chaplain Says He Passed On Mylai Allegations
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 3—A former Army chaplain told the court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson today that a helicopter pilot had informed him of “excessive civilian casualties” in the hamlet of Mylai. and that he had immediately, reported the allegations to his superior:
author: By Douglas Robinson;Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 IN CONGRESS ASK WAR PAPERS RULING
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) — Lawyers for two Congressmen asked a Federal judge today to read four volumes of the Pentagon Papers that are still classified to determine whether they should be made public.

headline: Saigon, Fearing Reduced Aid, May Cut Army
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 1—Afraid of possible cutbacks in American military aid, the South Vietnamese Government has begun seriously studying plans to demobilize 100,000 soldiers next year, and to put others into agricultural and industrial jobs..

headline: More Clashes in East Cambodia Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 3 (AP)—Fighting increased in Eastern Cambodia today as South Vietnam's troops continued their 12‐day‐old sweep, but action fell off in other Indochina sectors.

headline: Mrs. Hulse Plans Bridal
lead_paragraph: AUBURN, Me., Dec. 4— Mrs. Jolin Boucher Hulse, widow of Capt. Richard David Hulse, a helicopter pilot who died in action with the Air Force in Vietnam, plans to be married Dec. 18 in Southport, Conn., to David H. Feila Jr. of Southport.

headline: U. S. Attacks in North
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 4 (AP) — American fighter bombers attacked three air de fense radar sites inside North Vietnam, one of them 95 miles north of the demilitarized zone, the United States command re ported today.

headline: G.I.'s and O.J.'s In Vietnam
lead_paragraph: The space measured about 5 by 10 feet, contained two stacked bunks, a makeshift small chair and plain boards arranged as shelves. A thin wood and cloth partition about 5‐feet high provided only a little privacy from the rest of the barracks, which housed about 40 men. One of the men whose space this was had invited me in to rap about the Army in Vietnam and how E.M.'s (enlisted men) deal with the nonwar war. Others had anecdotes to add, and shortly 10 men had crowded into the space. As the discussion be came more animated, one man pulled out a cigarette and began to roll it between the thumb and forefinger of his left hand. After a while, I began to recognize this as a characteristic gesture. With his right hand he pulled from his pocket a small, greenish vial filled with white pow der and poured it into the partially emptied cigarette. He lit up, took a deep puff and passed the O.J. (opium joint) around. Most of those in the group took a hit, but two or three, including Tom, the 20‐year‐old host who had recently gotten himself off a 15‐vial‐a‐day habit, said, “No.
author: By Norman E. Zinberg

headline: No Survivors in Crash
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Dec. 4 (UPI)—Mili tary searchers today reached the wreckage of a United States Army Chinook helicopter that crashed on a jungled mountain last Sunday and reported there were no survivors among the 33 Americans aboard, the Unit ed States command announced.

headline: Grim Portent in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: The rout of Cambodian forces north of their capital despite strong American aerial support and diversionary maneuvers by the South Vietnamese offers fresh evi dence of the terrible vulnerability of President Nixon's Indochina policy.

headline: Susannah Buck to Wed
lead_paragraph: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Dec. 4 —Mr. and Mrs. W. Porter Buck have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Susannah Buck, to Mitchell K. Furman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Furman of Farmingdale. The prospec tive bridegroom served with the Army in South Vietnam. The wedding is planned for next fall.

headline: U.S. Supplies Bulletproof Vests To Some Asian and Latin Chiefs
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 — Nguyen Van Thieu, the Presi dent of South Vietnam, has a bulletproof vest, supplied by the United States, to wear during public appearances.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Thieu Rules Out an Imposed Settlement
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 4—President Nguyen Van Thieu in a speech attempting to allay widespread fears among Viet namese politicians and officials that the United States and China are planning to impose a Viet nam settlement, declared today that “any solution for the Viet nam war must come from the Vietnamese people.”
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Sailors Who Fled War Duty Are Awaiting Discharge
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 (AP)—Eight sailors who re fused to sail for Vietnam on the aircraft carrier Constella tion and sought sanctuary in a San Diego church are await ing discharge at the Treasure Island naval station here, Navy spokesman says.

headline: REFUGEE PROBLEM IN CAMBODIA LAID TO ALLIED BOMBS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 — A team of Government investiga tors has concluded in a report prepared for the General Ac counting Office that American and South Vietnamese bombing is contributing substantially to the growing refugee problem in Cambodia.

headline: New Troop Cuts Foreseen
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Dec. 4—Authorita tive American officials said today that American troop withdrawals would reduce the number of G.I.'s in Vietnam to 40,000 to 60,000 by next June 30.

headline: M'GOVERN FINDING PEACE A BIG ISSUE
lead_paragraph: WAUSAU, Wis., Dec. 5—The war in Indochina has always been a special preoccupation of Senator George McGovern.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The The New York Times

headline: More MIG Activity Over Laos Concerns U.S. Air Chief
lead_paragraph: PHUCAT, South Vietnam, Dec. 5—The Secretary of the United States Air Force, Rob ert C. Seamans Jr., expressing concern about the increased ac tivity of North Vietnamese MIG‐21 fighters over the Ho Chi Minh trail in Laos, said to day that this year, for the first time, the South Vietnamese Air Force would also be bombing the trail.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: ANTIWAR GROUPS TO PROTEST HERE
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND, Dec. 5—The antiwar movement, worried about the upcoming election year when many of its sup porters turn to the ballot rather than demonstrations, de cided this weekend to hold its next mass protest in April New York; the movement's traditional stronghold.
author: By Agis Salpukas Special to The New York Times

headline: 6 Killed in Upstate Fire
lead_paragraph: LOCKPORT, N. Y., Dec. (UPI)—Five members of a fam ily and a boarder who had just returned from Vietnam died to day when fire swept their two‐ story frame house in Cambria, which is near this seat of Ni agara County. The dead were identified as Charles McLaugh lin, 40 years old, his wife, Louise, 38; their children, Kathy, 15; Charles Jr., 13, and Debra, 8, and the boarder, George Hill, 20.

headline: General Discharges Given to 8 Sailors Who Avoided War
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 (AP)—Eight sailors who sought sanctuary in a San Diego church in October when the carrier Constellation sailed for Southeast Asia were given “general’ discharges under hon orable conditions” today, the Navy said.

headline: TIMES WINS AWARD ON PRESS FREEDOM
lead_paragraph: For its publication of the Pentagon papers, The New York Times has been chosen as the recipient of the University of Arizona's annual John Peter Zenger Award for “distin guished service to freedom of the press and the people's right to know,” the university an nounced yesterday.

headline: Final Witness Testifies at Henderson Court‐Martial
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 6— The 106th and final witness testified today at the court martial of Col. Oran‐K. Hender son, and both the defense and the prosecution began to pre pare arguments for the military judge's instructions on the law to the seven‐man jury.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: 18 Killed, Saigon Says
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 6 (AP)—The South Vietnamese command said that air strikes had killed 18 enemy soldiers from 7 to 25 miles inside Cam bodia in a corridor between the Chup and Mimot rubber planta tions. Both plantations are re ported to be base areas for Vietcong and North Vietnamese divisions.

headline: Laotian Retreat Reported
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. (Reuters)—Government forces today abandoned the strategic town of Saravane in southern Laos after an attack by two North Vietnamese battalions, informed sources said.

headline: Wallace Says Electoral College Deadlock in 1972 Is His Second Goal
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6—Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said today that “the second best thing” for him as a 1972 Presidential candidate would be to deadlock the Electoral Col lege and exact policy commit ments from President Nixon as the price of his re‐election.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Is Closing Sleazy Bars for G.I.'s
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 6—A quiet campaign to close the city's bars and reduce prostitution now that United States troops are scarcer is being carried out by City Hall at the request of President Nguyen Van Thieu.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Cathedral of St. John Is Site Of a Variegated Peace Rally

headline: Bodies Recovered in Crash
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam.. Dec. 6 (UPI) — The bodies of 34 Americans killed Nov. 29 in the Vietnam war's ‘second worst helicopter crash have been re covered, the United States command said today. Orig inally, only 33 servicemen were thought to have been aboard. The 34th body was found by a search team last week.

headline: Pressure by Enemy on Pnompenh Is Continuing
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 7 (AP)—Enemy forces kept up pressure near Pnompenh today with rockets, guns and mines. In the eastern part of the country, however, South Vietnamese forces met little resistance.

headline: Saigon May Free P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 8 (AP)—South Vietnam is preparing to release scores more North Vietnamese and Vietcong prisoners of war during forthcoming holidays in the hope that Hanoi will reciprocate by freeing American prisoners, official sources said today.

headline: HENDERSON DEFENSE LOSES DISMISSAL BID
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 7—The military judge at the courtmartial of Col. Oran K. Henderson denied today a series of defense motions that sought the dismissal of all charges against the 51‐year‐old combat officer.

headline: So Little Is Worth Trying
lead_paragraph: LONDON—The war in Vietnam has been a multiple, turning point; also shock to all established habits of political thinking.
author: By Stuart Hampshire

headline: WAR PAPERS PLEA DENIED BY JUDGE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7—A A Federal district judge denied today a suit by two Congress. men to compel the release of all or part of the still classified segments of the Pentagon Papers.

headline: Cambodians Trained By U S. in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: LONGHAI, South Vietnam —“Airborne! Airborne!” the Cambodian recruits holler in English as they crawl and wiggle in the mud under a long stretch of barbed wire.

headline: Jets Draw North's Fire
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 8 (AP)—The United States command today repulsed three air engagements over North Vietnam yesterday, but said that no American jets were hit by the surface‐to‐air missiles and anti‐aircraft artillery fired at them.

headline: Thieu Bids Farewell To Australian Troops
lead_paragraph: VUNGTATI, South Vietnam, Dec. 8 (Reuters)—President Nguyen Van Mien bid farewell to the last Australian combat troops in South Vietnam today as they sailed for home on the troopship Sydney.

headline: Bitter Fighting Reported as Foe Opens Nevv Drive on Pnompenh
lead_paragraph: SRE NGEI, Cambodia, Dec. 8 (Reuter) — Fighting raged outside this tiny hamlet nine miles south of Pnompenh this afternoon as 1,000 Government troops moved to block a Communist advance toward the capital from a new quarter.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Call him Special Ambassador Billy Graham. The evangelist, an old friend of President Nixon's, has been appointed as a member of the official delegation to the inauguration of William R. Tolbert as President of Liberia. The delegation, due in Monrovia Jan. 1, will be led by Mrs. Nixon and will include Bernard J. Lasker, chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange; Mrs. John H. Johnson, wife of the publisher of Ebony magazine; and Samuel Z. Westerfield Jr., the Ambassador to Liberia. Special Ambassador Graham will officiate at a thanksgiving service at Providence Baptist Church in Monrovia the day before the inauguration, which is set for Jan. 3.

headline: Mills Sees ‘Fighting Chancel’ For Democrats Next Year
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Dec. 8 (AP) —Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, described President Nixon today as a brilliant strategist but said that the Democrats had a “fighting chance” of beating him in 1972.

headline: Tax‐Reduction Bill Is Sent To President by Congress
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9—The first session of the 92d (Congress, fitfully struggling toward adjournment, passed and sent to the White House today the tax‐reduction legislation President Nixon requested as part of his economic stabilizaition program.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 Oppose Rehnquist
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9—The forces opposing William H. Rehnquist's nomination to the Supreme Court picked up their second Republican Senator today—Jacob K. Javits of New York—and their first Southerner, J. W. Fulbright of Arkansas.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: M'GOVERN, IN CITY, CRITICIZES MAYOR

headline: Pnompenh Troops Dig In, Refugees Flee
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 9 (AP)—Cambodian troops dug in around an important transmitter near the suburban villa of Premier Lon Nol today while United States and South Vietnamese aircraft tried to drive the enemy from positions west and south of Pnompenh.

headline: Vietnam's ‘Korean Solution’
lead_paragraph: The Administration's much‐bruited concept of a possible “Korean solution” for Vietnam appears to be taking on a new meaning.

headline: Laotian Positions Harassed
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 9 (Agence France ‐ Presse) — All Laotian positions on the Soloven Plateau have been bombarded; harassed and immobilized” by North Vietnamese forces, a Government spokesman said today.

headline: 2 Bases Shelled Near DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 9 (AP)—Just south of the demilitarized zone enemy gunners today shelled two South Vietnamese outposts. It was the first such attack in several weeks. The Saigon command said that 50 rocket and mortar rounds hit the two bases, but caused no casualties.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: This year's winner of the Elijah Parish Lovejoy Award, which recognizes a newspaperman of “integrity, craftsmanship, character, intelligence and courage,” is Erwin D. Canham, editor in chief of The Christian” Science Monitor. As the winner, Mr. Canham will address a convocation March 3 at Colby College, which administers the award in memory of Mr. Lovejoy, an 1826 graduate who was killed in Alton, Ill., in 1837 while defending his press against a mob that opposed his editorial stand against slavery.
author: Albin Krebs

headline: 2 Airmen Cleared of Distributing Peace Leaflets at Idaho Base
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN HOME AIR FORCE BASE, Idaho, Dec. 9—A few of the spectators at a special court‐martial exploded with joy, shouting “Wow” and pummeling the back of a young airman today as he was cleared of charges of illegally distributing peace literature at this fighter plane base in southwestern Idaho.
author: By Anthony Ripley Special to The New York Times

headline: Talks at Paris Fail For 1st Time to Set New Meeting Date
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 9—The Vietnam peace talks ended their 138th session today, and for the first time there was no agreement on when to meet again.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Army Drops Charges Against General Accused of Killing 6 South Vietnamese Civilians
lead_paragraph: The Army announced yesterday that it had dismissed murder and assault charges against Brig. Gen. John W. Donaldson, who, as an infantry brigade commander, was accused of killing six South Vietnamese civilians.
author: By Douglas Robinson

headline: Thieu's Backers Dominate Legislature
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 10—The legislators of South Vietnam's lower house finally made clear the results of last August's elections by organizing themselves this week into voting blocs that left the Government forces firmly in control.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Henderson Case to Be Sent To the Jury Next Thursday
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 10 (AP)—Closing arguments in the court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson will begin next Wednesday and the case will be submitted to the jury Thursday afternoon, the judge announced today.

headline: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen

author: By Richard L. Madden Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Residents Finding the Price Squeeze Worse Than Ever
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 8—Truong Hong Bac normally eats two meals a day but he is down to one now, skipping breakfast to save 27 cents a day.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Reports Heaviest Battle Of Its Operation in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 11 (AP)—North and South Vietnamese forces reportedly battled for nine hours yesterday deep inside Cambodia in the heaviest fighting of the Saigon command's three‐week‐old offensive across the border.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: President Nixon presented the Distinguished Service Medal to Gen. Leonard F. Chapman Jr., who is retiring Dec. 31 after four years as Marine Corps Commandant. At a ceremony in the White House Oval Office, Mr. Nixon said the Commandant had “nothing but a record of pride to look back on.” General Chapman said that among his fond memories as head of the corps was “clearly the performance, dedication and loyalty of the 450,000 Marines who fought in Vietnam.”
author: James F. Clarity

headline: Congress Leaders Break Deadlock Over Aid Funds
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10—A deadlock over foreign aid, the last major obstacle to adjournment, was broken today as Congressional leaders agreed to bypass a Senate amendment on the withdrawal of American troops from Vietnam.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Fighter Downed Over Laos By a North Vietnamese Missile
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 11—A United States Air Force jet fighter escorting a B‐52 raid over the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos was hit and destroyed by an enemy surfaceto‐air missile, the United States command disclosed today.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Expert's Bid Stirs Chicago U.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Dec. 11—The president of the University of Chicago rejected this week charges that Gerald C. Hickey, an expert on Vietnam, had been denied an academic appointment because of his association with the Rand Corporation, a private research organization under contract to the Defense Department.
author: By Andrew H. Malcolm Special to The New York Times

author: —Iver Peterson

headline: Hanoi Said to Harden Stand on P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) — State Department officials said today that North Vietnam had “completely dashed” Nixon Administration hopes that it had decided to improve the condition of the American prisoners of war.

headline: ‘If You Kill Somebody...’

headline: U.S. Jet Shot Down
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 11 (AP)—An intensification of surface‐to‐air missile attacks against United States warplanes and the first shooting down of an American jet in eight months from North Vietnam could trigger a new round of retaliatory blows against North Vietnam.

headline: Secret Cockfights Persist in Saigon, Despite Ban
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 11—In the 13th century, a popular Vietnamese legend runs, when the Mongols were poised to invade Vietnam, the famous general Tran Hung Dao called on his people to give up their addiction to cockfighting temporarily. headline: Thrust in Cambodia Is Deepest in Year

headline: Amnesty Bill for Foes of Draft Is Introduced in Senate by Taft

author: By Bill Kovach Special to The New York Times

headline: JURY IN MYLAI CASE TO HEAR ARGUMENTS
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 14 — The closing arguments by the defense and the prosecution in the court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson will be heard tomorrow by the jury of two generals and five colonels, who will probably begin their deliberations Thursday.

headline: Chup, in Cambodia, Seized, Saigon Says
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 14 (AP) —New fighting broke out on Cambodia's northeastern front today after South Vietnamese troops reported capturing the rubber plantation town of Chup in their offensive into eastern Cambodia.

headline: AGNEW ATTACKS ‘UTOPIAN LEFTISTS’
lead_paragraph: Vice President Agnew yesterday vigorously attacked “the utopian leftists who despair at how far we fall short of the ideal instead of howl close we have come to achieving it.”
author: By Thomas P. Ronan

headline: Nixon May Review Trip Unless Soviet Curbs. India
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14—The White House is letting it be known that President Nixon will reconsider his planned trip to Moscow unless the Soviet Union uses its influence with India to bring about cease‐fire in her war with Pakistan.
author: By James M. Naughon Special to The New York Times

headline: Colonel Called a ‘Disgrace’ and ‘Great’ in Trial Debate
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 15, — Col. Oran K. Henderson was portrayed today as a man who had brought “dishonor, disgrace and humiliation” to the uniform of the United States Army by his alleged concealment of the mass slaying of South Vietnamest civilians by American troops in the hamlet of Mylai 4.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Proposes Peace Talks Be Put Oil to Deco 30
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 15—William J. Porter who has been harsh with the Vietnamese Communists ever since he became the chief of the American delegation at the peace talks more than two months ago, was harsh with them again today. He proposed in effect a three‐week break in the discussions.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: LAO REFORM LAG FOUND IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Dec. 13 — An American‐sponsored program of land reform here is giving far less land than initially intended to the montagnards, the mountain people of Central Vietnam.

headline: Missile Site Attacked
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 15 (UPI)—No major fighting was reported in.South Vietnam today. But the United States Command in Saigon, in a delayed report, said that two United States Navy A‐7 Intruder jets fired on two North Vietnamese antiaircraft bases about 85 miles north of the demilitarized zone on Monday.

headline: BUCKLEY FORESEES '72 NIXON VICTORY
lead_paragraph: Senator James L. Buckley declared yesterday that he would put “good odds” on the reelection of President Nixon next year and that Vice President Agnew would be a “definile asset” if he were on the ticket.
author: By Thomas P. Ronan

headline: Two Americans Killed In Combat Last Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 16 (AP)—The United States command announced today that two Americans were killed in action in Vietnam last week, equaling the lowest official weekly toll in nearly seven years.

headline: What Innate Goodness?
lead_paragraph: Dr. Harvey Cox stated in his Dec. Op‐Ed article that if the “ordinary Americans” knew what was going on in Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam, they would be as outraged and shocked as they were over Mylai.
author: Mortimer T. Cohen; New York, Dec. 2, 1971

headline: CONGRESS BREAKS FOREIGN AID JAM; SEEKS TO AMON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 — Congress apparently broke today the impasse on foreign aid legislation that has been holding up adjournment as the House unexpectedly met Senate demands for a vote on an amendment on Vietnam troop withdrawal.
author: By John W. Finney; Special to The New York Times

headline: Seamans Says Build‐Up At Hanoi Suggests Push
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 — Secretary of the Air Force Robert C. Seamans Jr. said today that United States aircraft have observed a build‐up of Sovietmade and Chinese‐made transport trucks around Hanoi and Haiphong.

headline: U.S. F‐4 Downed at Pnompenh; 2 Cambodian Units Surrounded
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 16 (AP)—A United States Air Force fighter‐bomber crashed within sight of Pnompenh today while supporting Cambodian troops. Military sources said, that the plane had been hit by enemy ground fire.

headline: Patient Army Judge in Mylai Case Peter Stanislaus Wondolowski
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 16—For almost four months now, Col. Peter Stanislaus Wondolowski, employing a judicious mixture of wisdom, patience and humor, has kept the court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson moving steadily toward a verdict.

headline: ARMY JURY GETS HENDERSON CASE
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 16 — The case of Col. Oran K. Henderson went to a jury of two generals and five colonels this afternoon in the last courtmartial to arise from the slaying of South Vietnamese civilians by American troops at Mylai 4.
author: By Douglas Robinson; Special to The New York Times

headline: Light Action at Chup
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 16 (AP) — South Vietnamese spokesmen reported today that a 6,000‐man task force pushing through the Chup rubber plantation in eastern Cambodia had reached the east bank of the Mekong River, diectly across from Kompong Cham.

headline: Peking Shows Vietcong Film
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Dec. 17 (Reuters) —Representatives of diplomatic missions in Peking tonight were shown a film taken by a Vietcong camera team in South Vietnam of guerrillas operating openly in a village only two miles from an American base in the Central Highlands.

headline: Saigon Forces Leave Chup
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 17 (UPI) — South Vietnamese and Cambodian forces pulled out of the Chup rubber plantation today after failing to find an estimated 9,000 North Vietnamese troops reported by Allied intelligence to be hiding in the Communist sanctuary in eastern Cambodia.

headline: Col. Henderson Acquitted In Last of the Mylai Cases
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 17— Col. Oran K. Henderson, the infantry brigade commander whose troops shot down more than 100 civilians in the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 in March, 19G8, was acquitted today of charges that he had covered up the killings by an inadequate investigation.
author: By Douglas Robinson; Special to The New York Times

headline: An Enemy Missile Downs U.S Plane, Second in a Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 19—A North Vietnamese surface‐to‐air missile downed a United States Air Force F‐4 fighter‐bomber on the Laotian border late last night, and another missile was fired at the rescue forces that picked up the two crewmembers in Laos this morning, the United States; command said today.

headline: U.S. PROSECUTOR ON COAST RESIGNS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17— United States Attorney Robert L. Meyer of Los Angeles resigned today, and reliable sources said one reason was that he disagreed with the Justice Department's decision to prosecute Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.
author: By Steven V. Roberts; Special to The New York Times

headline: Only Caney Among 25 in Mylai Cases Was Convicted
lead_paragraph: With the acquittal yesterday of Col. Oran K. Henderson, First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. remains the only man to have been convicted of criminal charges for his role in the attack on the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 in March, 1968.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: Clash in Delta Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Dec. 17 (AP)—New fighting was reported today In the U Minh Forest.

headline: Allied Chiefs Meet in Pnompenh As Cambodian Posts Weaken
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 17, (UPI)—Cambodian positions on Route 6 north of Pnompenh deteriorated today under Com; munist pressure, according to military sources, who added that high‐level delegations of American and South Vietnamese officers had arrived here apparently to confer on the threat.

headline: Army Concedes the Use Of Metal Crates as Cells
Army Discharges Many Addicts in Vietnam Despite U.S. Pledges
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 18—The United States Army in Vietnam is discharging large numbers of heroin users despite pledges from President Nixon and the Pentagon to keep drug addicts in the Army for special help and rehabilitation.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: 3 U.S. Planes Reported Down in North Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Dec. 19 (UPI)—North Vietnamese gunners shot down three American planes deep in North Vietnam yes terday, the Hanoi radio said today.

headline: Law/Medicine
lead_paragraph: FT. MEADE, Md.—The massacre of South Vietnamese civilians by Ameri can soldiers in the undefended hamlet of Mylal 4 almost four years ago moved last week from a military courtroom into the pages of history.

headline: SAIGON TASK FORCE PULLS BACK AT CHUP
lead_paragraph: TAYNINH, South Vietnam, Dec. 18 (AP)—South Vietnamese forces are pulling back from enemy sanctuaries in eastern Cambodia for what high‐rank ing military sources call a “mo bile third phase” of their offen sive across the border.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: Some 5,000 American young men have gone to prison rather than be drafted and fight in Vietnam; 70,000 more have chosen exile. Last week, Senator Robert Taft Jr., Ohio Repub lican, introduced a bill in Congress that would grant them amnesty in re turn for some kind of alternate serv ice.

headline: GALLUP FINDS WAR DECLINES AS ISSUE
lead_paragraph: Concern about the Vietnam war has declined sharply among the American people, the Gal lup Poll reported yesterday.

headline: HANOI CHALLENGES AIR POWER OF U.S.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 19—The American air war in Indochina has entered a new phase, with direct confronta tions between American and North Vietnamese planes.
author: By Craig R. Wfiitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Foe Claims 4 Planes Downed
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 19 (AP) — Military spokesmen disclosed today that American fighter‐bombers exchanged mis sile fire with antiaircraft de fenses deep inside North Viet nam yesterday.

headline: Rockets Strike Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Monday, Dec. 20 (UPI)—Two rockets struck the Saigon waterfront area early today in the first such guer rilla attack since the Presiden tial election Oct. 3.

headline: Sensors Don't Bleed
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—At the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, Henry V's longbows helped to “stiffen the sinews, summon up the blood,” and carry the day against the French. Through the cen turies, the distance has continued to widen between warriors, until now in our own time proxy war is carried out by sophisticated weapons—and by Vietnamization.
author: By Herbert Mitgang

headline: Laotian Plain Overrun
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 20 (Reuters)—About 15,000 North Vietnamese troops, backed by tanks and heavy artillery, have overrun the strategic Plaine des Jarres in northern Laos, offi cials said today.

headline: U.S. and Saigon to Mark 3 Daylong Holiday Truces
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 20—President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that his armed forces would observe truces of 24 hours’ duration at Christmas, the New Year, and Tet, the lunar new year holi day, next Feb. 14. The United States command followed suit.

headline: Hanoi Lists 4 Captives
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 20 (UPI)—North Vietnam said today it had cap tured four United States airmen from three Phantom jets shot down Saturday.

headline: U.S. Confirms the Loss Of Four Jets Over Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 20—Four United States jet fighter‐bombers were shot down over northern Laos this weekend, and the American command here said at least one of them was ap parently destroyed in an air to‐air engagement with a North Vietnamese MIG‐21 that flew across the border to chalienge them.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. and Saigon to Mark 3 Daylong Holiday Truces
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 20—President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that his armed forces would observe truces of 24 hours’ duration at Christmas, the New Year, and Tet, the lunar new year holi day, next Feb. 14. The United States command followed suit.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, following the con viction of Lieut. William Calley for murdering 22 civilians during the mas sacre at Mylei, I was asked to uphold in a television debate the position that Calley was being made a scape goat for the guilt of many others, and should therefore be freed.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: With starvation in Vietnam, Pakis tan, India and in parts of our own United States, it seems heartless for us to anticipate and celebrate Christ mas by buying yet another plastic toy, another jewel, another gadget we will use and enjoy for a while and then set aside on the shelf.

headline: Saigon Asks Students Abroad to Return
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 20 — Early next year a South Vietnamese Government delegation will leave on round‐the‐world tour to per suade thousands of expatriate students to leave the comfort, fun and safety cf foreign uni versity life and go home.

headline: 9,200 Troops Pulled Out; U.S. Level Now 162,500
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam Dec. 20 (UPI) — Some 9,200 United States troops in the war zone, of South Vietnam last week in the largest seven‐day with drawal of Americans since 10, 200 servicemen left in a single week in April, 1970, the United States command said today.

headline: Laos Reports Enemy Drive
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 21 (Reuters) — North Vietnamese troops have begun a general offensive in Laos following their capture of the Plaine des Jarres in the north, a Laotian Government spokesman said here today.

headline: TV: ‘Vietnam Hindsight’ on the Kennedy Years
lead_paragraph: A two‐hour documentary by the National Broadcasting Company on the Vietnam de cisions of the Kennedy Ad ministration illustrates the limits television faces in seeking to meld into good history narration, film clips and retrospective interviews with surviving participants.
author: By Neil Sheehan

headline: Greater Protection Of Asian Art Urged
lead_paragraph: Distressed by the renewed, intense fighting in Cambodia with some rockets falling into Pnompenh, the capital, a committee of distinguished American art experts has ap pealed urgently to the De fense Department to take fur ther action to protect impor tant artistic monuments in Indochina.
author: By Howard Taubman

headline: Hanoi Condemns U.S.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Dec. 21— Bombardments of North Viet nam were condemned anew in Hanoi yesterday as four Amer ican pilots were shown at a news conference.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Concedes at Least One Jet Was Lost Near Hanoi
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 22 — The United States command con firmed this morning that one and possibly two of the four Air Force fighter‐bombers shot down or lost over the weekend crashed inside North Vietnam east of Hanoi while evading North Vietnamese MIG's that shot down another jet over Laos.
author: By Craig It Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: New Rules for Pilots
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22, (Reuters)—The Defense Department acknowledged today shift in policy, giving United States combat pilots greater freedom to attack anti‐aircraft missile sites in North Vietnam.

headline: News Policy for the Vietnam War: As Little as Possible
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 22—The American air war over Indochina has taken serious turn in recent months. The situation became dramatically apparent last weekend with the loss of four planes—but the news came first from Hanoi, not Saigon or Washington. The bombing campaign, as American officials in Washington and in South Vietnam h a v e been taking great pains to explain recently, is only half as big in numbers of planes and bomb tonnages as it was at the peak of United States involvement in 1968. The losses may have come as news to the American public but not to the North, Vietnamese, who continue to bear the brunt of heavy bombing on their supply trails in Laos if not in North Vietnam.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: 98 G.I.'s From Vietnam Visit Home Free
lead_paragraph: Unflawed holiday air travel, something usually reserved only for the most important dignitaries, was lavished yesterday at Kennedy International Airport on 98 servicemen home from Vietnam for the holidays.
author: By Murray Schumaci

headline: Soviet Charges That China Encourages Expansion of U. S. Aggression in Indochina
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 22—Pravda, the authoritative Communist party newspaper, charged today that China had given the United States “a green light for the expansion of aggression in South Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia” by bringing her foreign‐policy positions into line with Washington on number of other issues.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: 18 U.S. Prisoners of Vietcong Identified
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Cambodian Battle in 3d Day
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec., 22 (AP)—A Cambodian military spokesman said today that as a battle for the riverside village of Peam Chhkork, 46 miles north of here, entered its third day, North Vietnamese forces were so close to Government lines that allied warplanes were unable to bomb and strafe effectively.

headline: SAIGON TO FREE 689 IN HOLIDAY AMNESTY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 22—The South Vietnamese Government announced plans today to release 689 politcal prisoners as part of a holiday amnesty.

headline: Confidence on War Ebbs In the Cambodian Army
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 21—A growing awareness of the ability and toughness of North Vietnamese troops fighting in this country and a realization of the frailties of the Cambodian Army are causing deep uneasiness among many Cambodian commanders, who privately admit they are no longer confident about the outcome of the war.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Next Paris Session Dec. 30
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 22 — The North Vietnamese and Vietcong delegations at the peace talks here announced today their acceptance of an. American proposal to hold the next plenary session Dec. 30.

headline: U.S. Combat Deaths Listed; Toll Below 10 for 11th Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 23 (UPI) — The United States command said today that seven Americans were killed on the battlefields of Vietnam last week, the 1 1th week in a row in which there were fewer than 10 American combat deaths.

headline: Comment in Washington
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23—Government officials said today that while they were not informed in advance of Bob Hope's private efforts to win the release of United States prisoners of war, he was free to pursue them.

headline: ‘I Cannot Rejoice’
lead_paragraph: 1962—We were such newlyweds we counted Christmas day as our fourmonth anniversary. My husband had just begun Medical School. We didn't buy a tree (saving money) until at ten that night. We made much of trimming, then admitted that we missed our big family celebrations. The sleet turned to snow. By early morning we were on our way to our parents’ house.
author: By Valerie M. Kushner

headline: U.S. Jets Fire Missiles At 3 North Vietnam Sites
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 24—The United States command said today that Air Force F ‐105 fighter ‐bombers fired three missiles yesterday at three radar sites in the southern panhandle of North Vietnam near the Laotian border.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Debacle of Military Justice
lead_paragraph: When the horror of the events at a South Vietnamese hamlet named Mylai 4 was first disclosed two years ago, the sickening story of women, babies and old men murdered by American soldiers jolted the nation's conscience. President Nixon called it a massacre. Lieut. Gen. William Peers, who conducted a careful inquiry into the Army's preliminary handling of the charges, described Mylai as “a tragedy of major proportions.”

headline: Foe's Cease‐Fire Starts
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Dec. 23 (AP)—The Vietcong's three‐day Christmas cease‐fire went into effect at 1 A.M. today (noon, Thursday, New York time), but it was not expected to lessen hostilities in South Vietnam.

headline: ROGERS DECLARES U.S.WILL CONTINUE ASIAN AIR STRIKES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23—Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that United States warplanes would continue their strikes against enemy positions in Laos and Cambodia during 1972 to blunt the new North Vietnamese offensives in those areas.
author: By Malcolm W. Browne Special to The New York Times

headline: Hope Sees a Hanoi Aide in Laos; Seeks $10 Million Prisoner Deal
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 23 (UPI) — Bob Hope made a surprise visit to Vientiane, Laos, today to discuss with North Vietnamese officials the possibility of going to Hanoi to try to negotiate the release of. American prisoners of war in a $10‐million charity arrangement.

headline: Saigon Reports  Violations Of the Holiday Cease‐Fire
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 25—Christmas cease‐fires were in effect on both sides of the Vietnam war today, but the South. Vietnamese command said there had been 26 enemy violations of the truce.

headline: A French Priest's Vietnam Christmas
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 24—It pleases the Rev. Claude Collaudin that the creche made by Vietnamese children for his church shows Mary as an Asian woman, and Joseph in Vietnamese clothes. The children, uncertain of how the stable in Bethlehem might have looked instead built a but of dried coconut leaves, and the priest thought that was fine.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Civilians Quit Laos Base
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 24, (Reuters)—More than 2,000 civilians were evacuated from the key Laotian base of Long Tieng today as Government forces retreating from the neighboring Plaine des Jarres hurriedly formed a defense line on a mountain ridge to block advancing Vietnamese troops.

headline: First Letters From G.I.'s Held by the Vietcong Sound Much Alike
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24—The first letters ever to reach the United States from American prisoners of war in South Vietnam tend to sound much alike, generally refecting a tone of assurance that the prisoners are being adequately cared for.

headline: Nixon Is Appreciative
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) —President Nixon said today that he deeply appreciated Bob ;Hope's effort to seek the freedom of American prisoners of war.

headline: Hope Admits Doubt North Will Permit A Visit to P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: CAMP EAGLE, South Vietnam, Dec. 24 (AP) — Bob Hopel said today that he and a North ‘Vietnamese diplomat in Laos had discussed a children‐tochildren aid program and prisoner exchange.

headline: Pentagon Delays Decision On Releasing Mylai Report
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) — The Pentagon said today that a decision on whether to make public the full Army report of the Mylai killings would be made after all legal appeals and reviews in the case were completed.

headline: Cooke Reported Ready To Accompany Hope
lead_paragraph: William D. Fugazy, a travel agency executive, said yesterday that if Bob Hope succeeds in going to Hanoi to negotiate the release of American prisoners of war Cardinal Cooke will accompany him.

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON— North Vietnam's challenge to United States air power last week signaled a new and potentially more dangerous phase for President Nixon's air policy in Indochina.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25—There was not much Christmas spirit in Secretary of State Rogers’ message to Hanoi this week. In the coming year, he said, the United States would keep right on fighting the air war over Cambodia, northern Laos, the Ho CM Minh Trail and North Vietnam itself.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: Comedian Bob Hope for years has taken a troupe to Vietnam at Christmas to entertain American troops and “boost their morale.” He has gagged his way from base to base, only occasionally getting serious about the course of the war.

headline: BOB HOPE AWAITING HANOI AIDE'S REPLY
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 25 (AP) — Bob Hope, returning from his annual Christmas tour in South Vietnam, said today that he was still trying to arrange for a visit to prisonerof‐war camps in the North.

headline: Vast U.S. Raids Foreseen
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Sunday, Dec. 26 (AP)—The United States is planning vast new air strikes against previously untouched military targets in North Vietnam, Representative Gillespie V. Montgomery, Democrat of Mississippi, said today.

headline: Much U.S. Mail to P.O.W.'s Ends Up in a Paris Cellar
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 25 (AP)—Just over a year agO, 10‐year‐old Mary Hendrix painted a pinkand‐green Christmas card sprinkled with snowflakes and mailed it to An American prisoner in North Vietnam.”

headline: CHRISTMAS TRUCE ENDS IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Dee. 26 (UP)—Alfed troops went back to war yesterday after a 24‐hour Christmas truce, No American combat deaths were reported during the holiday cease‐fire that ended at sundown.

headline: Bond Is Back — and ‘Diamonds’ Got Him
lead_paragraph: IAN FLEMING was one of John F. Kennedy's favorite authors, and, when you think about it, the JFK years were often a lot like Ian Fleming's novels, with sexy personalities, amazing technologies and an atmosphere of constant, cosmic peril. Remember the Missile Gap, the Bay of Pigs, the Cuban Missile Crisis, the Green Berets, crash funding for NASA, Red aggression in Vietnam? It was great theater, involving vast expenditures of money and adrenalin, and a national audience teetered between exhilaration and panic. It was also about that time that two bright men named Harry Saltzman and Albert R. Broccoli cashed in on this audience's hunger for more of the same by commencing to produce James Bond movies.
author: By Peter Schjeldahl

headline: Again, ‘Rolling Thunder’
lead_paragraph: Escalation of American bombing of North and South Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos in recent days flies in the face of Administration promises that the United States is withdrawing from a combat role. The Demilitarized Zone has become a phantom; American fighter‐bombers are ranging closer to Hanoi in operations that call up memories of the heavy air war of the past. The risks are formidable—for the engaged fliers and for the chances of peace.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hanoi Legal Official Charges Corruption At Important Levels
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 —North Vietnam's chief law‐enforcement officer has charged that corruption, waste and defiance of. Communist party pol icies are occurring on important levels in North Vietnam.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Police See More Military Arms in Use
lead_paragraph: Police officials say that the use of a United States Army fragmentation grenade against two policemen last Monday was symptomatic of an upsurge in the illegal use and possesion of Vietnam war‐type military equipment in the city.
author: By Eric Pace

headline: Attacks Called ‘Prelude’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26—A United States official who declined to be identified said today that the raids on North Vietnam were a “prelude” to intensified United States strikes against the North Vietnamese ground forces fighting on the Plaine des Jarres in northern Laos.

headline: Hanoi Sources in Laos Negative on Hope Visit
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 26 (Agence France‐Presse)—Sources at the North Vietnamese Embassy here said today that there was absolutely no chance that Bob Hope would be allowed to enter North Vietnam under present circumstances.

headline: U.S. PLANES STAGE LARGE‐SCALE RAW ON NORTH VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 27— States Air Force and Navy planes attacked military installations in North Vietnam yesterday and today, the American command announced.

headline: Foe said to Rise Crops on Trail
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 26—A recent account of an effort to improve the morale of North Vietnamesetroops bn the Ho Chi Minh supply trail describes the growing of green vegetables and the raising of chickens and small hogs by troops on operations.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Cease‐Fire Period Is the Quietest of the War
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 26 (Reuters) — Christmas ceasefires on Vietnam's battlefields dnded tonight after the war's quietest truce period. Thirteen South Vietnamese soldiers were reported killed. No American deaths were reported.

headline: Air War Intensifies
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Dec. 26—The air strikes against North Vietnam followed by a week Serious intensification of the air war over Laos, when North Vietnamese MIG‐21 jet fighter‐bombers crossed the border and clashed with Amerlean planes supporting Laotian ground troops on the Plaine des Jarres.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Sailor Back From Exile a Symbol of Deserters’ Plight
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Dec. 26 — Jimmy Zwicker, carrying the scars of combat, has come home from the war, in shackles.
author: By Bill Kovach Special to The New York Times

headline: War Foes Seize Statue of Liberty
lead_paragraph: Sixteen antiwar veterans seized control of the Statue of Liberty last night and vowed to stay there until New Year's Eve as a protest against continuation of the war in Vietnam.
author: By Robert D. McFadden

headline: Hanoi Report Describes Shooting Down of 2 Jets
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 27 (UPI)—The North Vietnamese delegation to the Paris peace talks released today what it described as an eyewitness account written by the Vietnamese News Agency of how two American Phantom jets were shot down Dec. 26 at the bridge of Hamrong. headline: 70,000 to 100, 000 Young Men Could Face Prosecution
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Dec. 27—Although exact figures on the total number of Americans who are deserters or draft evaders are not available, the following statistics give an idea of the scope of the problem:

headline: U.S. Again Relying Heavily on Airpower to Achieve Its Objectives in Indochina
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27—Nearly seven years after President Lyndon B. Johnson began sustained bombing of North Vietnam in an effort to save the South, another American President is relying heavily on airpower to achieve his objectives in Indochina.
author: By Neil Sheehan Special to The New York Times

headline: Troops Cut to 158,300
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 27 (UPI)—The United States command said today that American troop strength dropped to 158,300 men as of last Thursday.

headline: Heavy American Bombing Of North Goes Into 3d Day
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 28—Heavy American bombing raids against North Vietnam went into the third consecutive day this morning while the United States command kept its official silence about details of the attacks and allied losses.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Congressmen Score Bombings
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27—Antiwar forces on Capitol Hill reacted quickly to the news of the massive bombing raids on North Vietnam.

headline: 25 War Protesters Are Held After Seizing Betsy Ross House
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27—Twenty‐five antiwar demonstrators occupied the Betsy Ross House here for an hour today in protest against continuation of the war in Vietnam. All were arrested.

headline: HUMPHREY URGES HALT IN BOMBING
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27—Senator Hubert H. Humphrey accused the Nixon Administration today of escalating the war in Southeast Asia and called for a “total cessation” of the bombing of North Vietnam.
author: By John Noble Wilford Special to The New York Times

headline: LAIRD WARNS BIG U.S. RAIDS IN NORTH MAY BE REPEATED TO PROTECT G.I.'S IN SOUTH
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27—Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird warned North Vietnam today that large‐scale bombing raids like the ones mounted by American bombers over the weekend might be repeated occasionally.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: 67% in Survey on Caney Say Most People Would Shoot Civilians if Ordered
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27—A Harvard survey of public attitudes toward First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. has found that two‐thirds of those questioned said that most people would shoot unarmed civilians if ordered to do so.
author: By Richard D. Lyons Special to The New York Times

headline: Laotians Evacuate 30,000 From Periled Long Tieng
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 27 (Reuters)—The Laotian Government has evacuated 30,000 women and children from Long Tieng, site of the military base that is seriously threatened by North Vietnamese troops following their sweep across the nearby Plaine des Jarres.

headline: Soviet Denounces Raids
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 27 (UPI)—The Soviet press agency Tass today called the intensified United States bombing of North Vietnam “provocative and adventuristic.”

headline: National Drive Seeks Amnesty For Deserters and Draft Evaders
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Dec. 27 — A national debate is growing around the issue of amnesty for thousands of young men who have avoided or deserted from service in the Vietnam war.
author: ByBill Kovach Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Copters Downed
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Tuesday, Dec. 28 (AP) — Communist‐led forces shot down seven United States helicopters supporting South Vietnamese militiamen in a daylong operation yesterday 27 miles northwest of Saigon, military spokesmen reported today.

headline: Excerpts From Laird's News Conference on Bombing of North and Defense Department Activities in ‘71
lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a news conference by Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: War Foes Reject U.S. Plan to Reopen Statue of Liberty
lead_paragraph: Vietnam veterans barricaded inside the Statue of Liberty yesterday rejected a Government compromise designed to reopen the historic monument to the public while allowing the veterans to continue their antiwar protest.
author: By Lawrence Van Gelder

headline: PLATEAU TOWN LOST TO THE FOE IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: VIETIANE, Laos, Dec. 28 (UPI)—North Vietnamese troops scored another victory today in a drive southward through Laos, capturing the town of Paksong and giving them control, of virtually the entire Boloven Plateau.

headline: More Pilots Reported Captured
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Dec. 28—The Hanoi radio, in a broadcast monitored here today, quoted the North Vietnamese Army newspaper Quan Doi Nhan Dan as having said that more United States pilots had been captured and that no American pilots held in North Vietnam would he freed as long as President Nixon continued the war.

headline: 87 Arrested in Protest At Lincoln Memorial
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28—Eighty‐seven members of the Vietnam Veterans Against the War were arrested for disorderly conduct today after blocking the entrance to: the Lincoln Memorial.

headline: U.S.BOMBING RAIDS ON NORTH VIETNAM ENTER FOURTH DAY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 29— United States bombing raids on North Vietnam went into a fourth day this morning, continuing the longest sustained series of attacks since the daily bombing ended in 1968.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Both Sides Cancel Session of Paris Peace Talks
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 28—The stepup in the air war over North Vietnam led to a further breakdown in the Paris peace talks today as both sides rushed to cancel the session scheduled for Thursday.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Soviet Denounces U.S. Raids on North
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 28—The Soviet press today sharply stepped up its protests against American bombing of North Vietnam and accused China of maintaining an awkward silence apparently because it did not want to spoil the atmosphere for President Nixon's visit to Peking in February.

headline: 15 Veterans Leave the Statue of Liberty, Claiming a Victory in Take‐Over
lead_paragraph: Proclaiming victory for their gesture with cheers and raised fists, 15 antiwar veterans ended their occupation of the Statue of Liberty yesterday.
author: By Michael T. Kaufman

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28—It has become evident here, despite varying official explanations for the renewed heavy bombing of North Vietnam, that the central purpose of the Nixon Administration is to stave off a major military setback in Indochina. The Administration apparently has coneluded that even in an election year the domestic political price f or such “limited‐duration” raids against the North by hundreds of planes will be less than the political consequences of a major military defeat in Indochina.
author: By Neil Sheehan Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Limited’ Air War?
lead_paragraph: Three days of large‐scale American air attacks against North Vietnam have dramatically shattered the Administration‐fostered myth that President Nixon is effectively winding down the war in Indochina. They also refute assertions by Secretary of State Rogers and Secretary of Defense Laird that the President's program of Vietnamization has been a “success.”

headline: AMERICAN PLANES BEGIN A FIFTH DAY OF RAIDS IN NORTH
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 30 — United States planes began their fifth successive day of bombing and strafing over North Vietnam this morning as the heaviest air raids against the North in more than three years con tinued without let‐up.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: HISTORIANS ASSESS PENTAGON PAPERS
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon papers were roundly criticized as poor history‐writing here tonight by Ernest R. May, a Harvard his tory professor.
author: By Henry Tanner

headline: U.S. Copter Shot Down
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 29—The United States command reported today that an Army light observation helicopter had been shot down just inside Cambodia while sup porting a South Vietnamese operation and two American crewmen were wounded.

headline: LINDSAY STARTS WISCONSIN RACE
lead_paragraph: EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Dec. 20 —Mayor Lindsay conceded to day that he did not have the support of “colorful, big‐shot” officials in his “lonely fight” for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
author: By Frank Lynn Special to The New York Times

headline: Cardinal Cooke Begins Visit to G.I.'s in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec.29 (AP)—Cardinal Cooke arrived in ‘Saigon. Today to begin his fourth Christmas‐ season trip to Vietnam.

headline: U.S.Diplomats in Vietnam Said to Face Moral Issue
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29—As signments to Vietnam—par ticularly to the pacification programs there—have caused many young career diplomats to face a serious “moral dilem ma,” according to an article in the December issue of the For eign Service Journal.
author: By Benjamin Welles Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Indignation’ in Peking
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Thursday, Dec. 30—China today expressed “ut most indignation” at the latest upsurge of American bombing in North Vietnam and promised continued “firm and unshak able” support of the forces in the Indochina war arrayed against the United States.

headline: Hanoi Identifies U.S. Pilots
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 29 (AP) — The North Vietnamese News Agency today gave the names of two American airmen reported killed when their Phantom jet was shot down Sunday. The names were given as Capt. Lawrence Gene Stolz, serial number 316464799 FR, and Lieut. Dale Francis Koons, serial number 275468109 FV.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's chosen policy of “Vietnamization” has greatly reduced the number of American troops and casualties in Indochina, while the non‐ Communist Government in Saigon has remained in power and—some say— strengthened itself. Can it be said, therefore, that Vietnamization has been a success?
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: U.S. Still Refusing to Give Any Details on the Bombing
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29—De spite mounting criticism, the Nixon Administration con tinued its refusal today to pro vide any information about the details or duration of the in tensified bombing of North Vietnam.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: 18 Veterans Arrested At Consulate on Coast
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 (AP)—Eighteen members of the Vietnam Veterans Against the War barricaded them selves inside the South Viet namese consulate today to protest renewed American bombing of North Vietnam and to demand an end to the war. They were arrested for trespassing.

headline: Pilots Describe ‘Shooting War’ In Skies Over Indochina Now
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, Dec. 29 (AP)—American pilots bombing North Vietnam are en countering more MIG's, sur face‐to‐air missiles and anti aircraft fire than they ever have seen before in Indochina.

headline: When G.I.'s Come Home, So Do Pets
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam —When many G.I.'s leave Vietnam, they do not leave behind their loved ones. In 1969, for example, American soldiers took home 270 dogs, 33 cats, 19 reptiles, 20 monkeys, 26 birds, one fox and three lizards.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Pentagon Says Hanoi Bans Some Parcels for P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29— The Pentagon said today that North Vietnam had refused to accept 900 packages mailed to American prisoners of war and men listed as missing in action.

headline: Pope Deplores ‘Bombings’
lead_paragraph: ROME, Dec. 29 — Pope Paul Ⅵ implicitly condemned the United States air strikes against North Vietnam in an address during his weekly general au dience in the Vatican today.

headline: In Cortland County They Remember the Servicemen
lead_paragraph: CORTLAND, N.Y., Dec. 30 —“You think you'd get used to it, but you never do,” mused Mrs. Grace Lindley, who for the last 14 years has always had at least one of six sons away in military service.
author: By Murray Schumach; Special to The New York Times

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30—Nineteen hundred and seventy‐one went out with a bang and a doubt. Between Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, President Nixon appealed first for human peace and pity, and then ordered the heaviest bombing of North Vietnam in over three years, and no body was quite able to reconcile the gentle words, and the destructive bombs.
author: By James Reston

headline: 9 Antiwar Veterans Seized
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP)—Nine members of the Vietnam Vet erans Against the War were arrested today after they and others occupied a Marine Corps recruiting station. The veterans occupied the station along with members of the People's Coali tion for Peace and Justice and supporters of both groups.

headline: Ellsberg Indicted Again in Pentagon Case
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30—Dr. Daniel Ellsberg was indicted by a Federal grand jury again today, on 12 criminal charges, including conspiracy, for re leasing the controversial Penta gon papers to the news media.
author: By Steven V. Roberts; Special to The New York Times

headline: One U.S. Combat Death Is Lowest Toll Since '65
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 30 (UPI)—One American soldier was killed in combat in Indochina last week, the United States military com mand reported today. It was the lowest, figure since Feb urary, 1965, when no one was killed. The command also re ported 29 wounded in the week ended Saturday.

headline: Saigon Ends Cambodia Drive
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Dec. 30 (AP)— Some 25,000 South Vietnamese troops today ended a 39‐day drive in eastern Cambodia against staging areas of three North Vietnamese divisions. The campaign along Route 7 was designed to head off a dry season offensive into Military Region of South Vietnam, ‘which includes Saigon and 11 surrounding provinces.

headline: Accounts of U.S. Air Attacks Broadcast by the Hanoi Radio
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec 30—The trembling voice of a 14‐year‐old North Vietnamese girl saying that members of her family were killed by American bombs was broadcast several times yesterday and today by the Hanoi radio.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Moscow Assails U. S.
lead_paragraph: MOCOW, Dec. 30—The So viet Government denounced today the five‐day bombing campaign of the United States against North Vietnam and said it belied the assurances of Washington that it sought to withdraw from the conflict in Indochina.

headline: Academic Meetings: Study of War Urged;
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30— William P. Bundy, one of the influential policy makers of the Vietnam war, conceded today that American military plan ners might have let convention al war get out of hand in their direction of the conflict in Southeast Asia.
author: By John Noble Wilford Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. BOMBERS END INTENSIFIED RAIDS ON NORTH VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 30—The United States command announced today the end of its intensified bombing of North Vietnam after five days of raids. It also stated for the first time that the targets of the heaviest attacks against the North in three years—in volving 1,000 strikes—were air fields, supply depots and anti‐ aircraft sites.
author: By Iver Peterson; Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnamese Called Ellsberg Co‐Conspirator Is an Economist
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 30 — Vu Van Thai, named today as a co‐conspirator with Dr. Daniel Ellsberg in the case of the Pentagon papers, is now in Dakar, Senegal, working as a consultant on a river devel‐, opment project for the United Nations Development Program.
author: By Kathleen Teltsch Special to The New York Times

headline: Ellsberg Denies Charges
lead_paragraph: Dr. Ellsberg contended yes terday that the Government's charges against him were “false” and that he was not aware of having “violated any criminal statutes.”
author: By Douglas Robinson
